metrics.name: Amount of time spent on dropouts
metrics.description: Total cycle time of all cases until the last event before dropout
metrics.signalFragment:
SUM(
	(SELECT LAST(end_time)) - (SELECT FIRST(end_time))) FILTER (
		WHERE (SELECT LAST(event_name) IN (${dropout_events}))
   )

metrics.name: Unpaid Invoices with Non Evaluated Risk Class
metrics.signalFragment: COUNT (1) AS "Case Count"

metrics.name: Invoice Payment Compliance Rate
metrics.signalFragment: (COUNT (1) FILTER (WHERE EVENT_NAME MATCHES ('Create Invoice'~> 'Receive Payment')) / COUNT (1)) * 100 AS "Standard Invoicing Compliance Rate"

metrics.name: Median Returns Cycle Time
metrics.signalFragment: MEDIAN ((SELECT LAST (END_TIME) WHERE EVENT_NAME = 'Receive Return') - (SELECT FIRST (END_TIME) WHERE EVENT_NAME = 'Create Return Request')) AS "Median Return Cycle Time"

metrics.name: Average cycle time
metrics.description: Average cycle time calculated from the first to the last event
metrics.signalFragment: AVG((SELECT LAST(end_time)) - (SELECT FIRST(end_time)))

metricVariables.name: dropout_events
metricVariables.description: Events that identify a dropout case, for example 'Reject Quote', 'Update Opportunity Stage to: Dead - No Decision'

dataSource.query: SELECT count(case_id) FROM THIS_PROCESS

blocks.text: This investigation was created to demonstrate some (process agnostic) mining use cases in Process Intelligence to support the AskData SIGNAL NLP Proof of Concept.
This template, along with the underlying data source is to be shared with our colleagues at AskData to train an NLP algorithm to translate simple process type questions into SIGNAL code.
The data source is an Order To Cash Process, however the example SIGNAL can be used for any process type.
The shape of the process data is outlined in the value widgets below
Each widget is configured with custom SIGNAL demonstrating query syntax for specific mining scenarios.

dataSource.query: SELECT count(case_id) FROM THIS_PROCESS

SELECT count(1) 
FROM FLATTEN(THIS_PROCESS)

SELECT count(1) / count(distinct case_id)
FROM FLATTEN(THIS_PROCESS)
SELECT count(DISTINCT event_name) FROM THIS_PROCESS

children.name: Cycle Time Example 1: Average cycle time across all cases

blocks.text: The Value Widget below is configured to show the average cycle time across all cases.
Cycle time is the time between two recorded events, in this case the first and last recorded event across all cases.

dataSource.query:
SELECT AVG((SELECT LAST(end_time) - FIRST(end_time))) AS "Average Cycle Time"
FROM THIS_PROCESS

children.name: Cycle Time Example 2: Median Cycle Time between Specific Events

blocks.text: The Value Widget below is configured to show the median cycle time for returns processing, ie the median cycle time between creating a return request and receiving the return.

Cycle time is the time between two recorded events, in this case the first recorded instance of the 'Create Return Request' event, and last recorded instance of the 'Return Received' event across all cases.

dataSource.query:
SELECT MEDIAN(
			   (SELECT LAST(end_time) 
			    WHERE event_name = 'Receive Return')
			    -
               (SELECT FIRST(end_time) 
                WHERE event_name = 'Create Return Request')
             ) AS "Median Return Cycle Time"
FROM THIS_PROCESS

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table Widget below is configured to show the top 5 process variants with their Average Cycle Times, ranked according to Case Count.
A process variant is a unique sequence of recorded events in a process (sometimes referred to as a trace).

children.name: Top 5 Variants and their Average Cycle Time, ranked by Case Count

dataSource.query:
SELECT event_name AS "Variant", 
  	   COUNT(DISTINCT case_id) as "Case Count",
       AVG((SELECT LAST(end_time) - FIRST(end_time))) AS "Average Cycle Time"
  FROM THIS_PROCESS
 GROUP BY 1
 ORDER BY 2 DESC
 LIMIT 5

children.name: Variant Example 2: Top X Variants by Percentile

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table Widget below is configured to show the maximum cycle time of 90% of all cases within each variant. For the purposes of the demo, we limit the results to the top 5 results.
A process variant is a unique sequence of recorded events in a process (sometimes referred to as a trace).

children.name: Top 5 Variants ranked by 90th Percentile Cycle Time

dataSource.query:
SELECT event_name AS "Variant", 
	  PERCENTILE_DISC(0.9) WITHIN GROUP(ORDER BY (SELECT LAST(end_time) - FIRST(end_time))) AS "90th Percentile Cycle Time per Variant"
  FROM THIS_PROCESS
 GROUP BY 1
 ORDER BY 2 DESC
 LIMIT 5

children.name: Rework Example 1: Cases with X repeated events

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table Widget below is configured to show cases with rework. Rework is identified by a number of repeated process steps exceeding a given threshold.
In this example, we show cases that have at least 1 event that is repeated at least 3 times.

children.name: Cases with Rework (Any event repeated more than 3 times)
children.description: Rework means the same event_name occurrent multiple times in the same case

dataSource.query:
SELECT case_id, "event_name", "end_time", "Risk Class" 
FROM THIS_PROCESS
WHERE (SELECT MAX(occ)
       FROM (SELECT OCCURRENCE(event_name) AS occ) AS sub) > 3
ORDER BY 1

children.name: Compliance Example 1: Compliance Rate for Standard Invoice Processing

blocks.text: The value widget below is configured to show the compliance rate for standard invoicing with payment received.
Compliance rate represents the count of cases exhibiting specific patterns / behaviours / sequences of events, divided by the total number of cases.
In this example we combine SIGNAL FILTER and MATCHES expressions count cases exhibiting a specific event pattern.

dataSource.query:
SELECT (
		COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE event_name MATCHES ('Create Invoice'~> 'Receive Payment'))
       /
       COUNT(1)
       ) * 100 AS "Standard Invoicing Compliance Rate"

FROM THIS_PROCESS

children.name: Pattern Matching Example 1: Unpaid Invoices (Standard Process Deviation)

blocks.text: The value widget below is configured to show the count of cases where invoice payment has not been received and customer risk class has not been assessed.

We calculate this by counting the cases exhibiting specific behaviours, specifically where the case level attribute 'Risk Class' = 'Not Evaluated' and the event 'Create Invoice' is not followed by the event 'Receive Payment' or 'Cancel Invoice'.
A behaviour is an expression evaluating case or event level attributes and can be used in a pattern matching expression.

children.name: Unpaid Invoices with Non Evaluated Risk Class

dataSource.query:
SELECT COUNT(1) AS "Case Count"
FROM THIS_PROCESS
WHERE "Risk Class" = 'Not evaluated'
AND
BEHAVIOUR
         (event_name = 'Create Invoice') AS create_invoice,
         ("Risk Class" = 'Not evaluated') AS no_risk_evaluation
MATCHES (no_risk_evaluation ~> create_invoice)
AND 
NOT event_name MATCHES ('Create Invoice' ~> 'Receive Payment')
AND
NOT event_name MATCHES ('Create Invoice' ~> 'Cancel Invoice')

children.name: Pattern Matching Example 2: Unpaid Invoices by Risk Class (Standard Process Deviation)

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table widget below is configured to show the count of cases where invoice payment has not been received according to customer risk class.

We calculate this by counting the cases exhibiting specific behaviours, specifically the event 'Create Invoice' is not followed by the event 'Receive Payment' or 'Cancel Invoice', and group the result by the case level attribute 'Risk Class'.
A behaviour is an expression evaluating case or event level attributes and can be used in a pattern matching expression.

children.name: Cases by Risk Class where Issued Invoice was neither followed by payment or cancelation

dataSource.query:
SELECT "Risk Class", 
	   COUNT(1) AS "Case Count"
FROM THIS_PROCESS
WHERE event_name 
MATCHES ('Create Invoice')
AND
NOT event_name 
MATCHES ('Create Invoice'
		~> 'Receive Payment')
AND
NOT event_name 
MATCHES ('Create Invoice'
		~> 'Cancel Invoice')
GROUP BY 1
ORDER BY 2 DESC

children.name: Timeseries Example 1: Active Cases within Period

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table widget below is configured to show the count of active cases per time period, meaning cases that were started at or before that period but not yet ended. In this example we consider the time period aggregated by months.

We calculate this by calculating a running count of first (case opened) and last (case closed) events per month. We then use the LAG function to subtract the previous period closed cases from the current period opened cases running count to get the total number of active cases started at or before the month but not yet ended.

dataSource.query:
SELECT "Month"
	   ,count_started AS "Cases Started During Month"
       ,count_finished AS "Cases Completed During Month"
       ,IF(count_started IS NOT NULL, count_started, 0) - IF(LAG(count_finished) OVER () IS NOT NULL, LAG(count_finished) OVER (), 0) AS "Active Cases"
  FROM (SELECT "Month"
             , SUM(count_started) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_started
             , SUM(count_finished) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_finished
          FROM (SELECT "Month"
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 1) AS count_started
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 0) AS count_finished
                  FROM (SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT FIRST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                  			   1 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS
                        UNION ALL
                        SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT LAST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                               0 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS) AS sub
                 GROUP BY 1
                 FILL TIMESERIES('month')
               ) AS sub2
       ) AS sub3

children.name: Time Series: Active cases by month

dataSource.query:
SELECT "Month"
       ,IF(count_started IS NOT NULL, count_started, 0) - IF(LAG(count_finished) OVER () IS NOT NULL, LAG(count_finished) OVER (), 0) AS "Active Cases"
  FROM (SELECT "Month"
             , SUM(count_started) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_started
             , SUM(count_finished) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_finished
          FROM (SELECT "Month"
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 1) AS count_started
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 0) AS count_finished
                  FROM (SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT FIRST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                  			   1 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS
                        UNION ALL
                        SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT LAST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                               0 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS) AS sub
                 GROUP BY 1
                 FILL TIMESERIES('month')
               ) AS sub2
       ) AS sub3

metrics.name: Percentage of reversed invoices

	WHERE event_name MATCHES(${itc_invoice_reversal_events}))
/
COUNT(case_id)
* 100

metrics.name: On-time payment rate
metrics.description: Percentage of invoices that were cleared less than 5 days before and no later than 1 day after their due dates

metrics.name: Percentage of change events per case
metrics.description: Average percentage of change events per case

metrics.name: Total overdue invoice amounts
metrics.description: Sum of all invoice amounts that are overdue (converted in USD)
metrics.signalFragment:
SUM(${itc_amount_conv}) FILTER(
	 WHERE (${itc_clearing_date} IS NULL)
		AND ${itc_due_date} < DATE_TRUNC('day', NOW())
	)

metrics.name: On-Time Delivery raten
metrics.description: Percentage of cases with on-time deliveries. Only cases that have been completely delivered are considered.

metrics.name: Two-way match ratehu
metrics.description: Percentage of purchase orders with a two-way match
metrics.signalFragment:
COUNT(case_id) FILTER (
	WHERE (${two_way_match_condition})
	)
/ COUNT(case_id)
* 100

metrics.name: On-time delivery rate
metrics.description: Percentage of deliveries arriving at their destination before or on the expected date
metrics.signalFragment:
COUNT(case_id) FILTER (
	WHERE (SELECT COUNT(event_name)
			WHERE (${ontime_delivery_condition})) > 0
	)
/ COUNT(case_id) FILTER (
	WHERE (SELECT BOOL_OR(event_name IN (${outbound_delivery_creation_events})))
	) 
* 100

metrics.name: Overdue deliveries casesn,
metrics.description: Number of cases with overdue deliveries. Only cases that have not been (completely) delivered yet are considered.

metrics.name: Net average cycle time spent on rework
metrics.description: Difference between the average cycle time of the cases that have any rework and the average cycle time of the whole process

metrics.name: Process orders specific status
metrics.description: Total process orders with a specific status
metrics.signalFragment:
COUNT(event_name)
	FILTER(WHERE event_name MATCHES(${mts_po_status_event_name}))

metrics.name: Late deliveries casesö
metrics.description: Number of cases with late deliveries. Only cases that have been completely delivered are considered.

COUNT(case_id) FILTER (
	WHERE event_name MATCHES(${itp_invoice_reversal_events}))
/
COUNT(case_id)
* 100

metrics.description: Total number of cases with Invoices waiting for the Goods Receipt event

COUNT(case_id) FILTER (
	WHERE NOT (event_name MATCHES(${ato_goods_receipt_events}))
	AND (event_name MATCHES(${ato_invoice_event_flow}))
	)

AVG(
	(SELECT LAST(end_time)
		WHERE event_name IN (${invoice_clearing_events}))
	-(SELECT FIRST(end_time)
		WHERE event_name IN (${invoice_receipt_events}))
   )

metrics.name: Overdue deliveries casesnm
metrics.description: Number of cases with overdue deliveries. Only cases that have not been (completely) delivered yet are considered.

	WHERE (${late_payment_condition})
	)
/ COUNT(case_id) FILTER (
	WHERE (${invoice_clearing_date} IS NOT NULL)
	)
* 100

metrics.description: Percentage of invoices that were cleared less than 5 days before and no later than 1 day after their due dates

metrics.name: On-Time Delivery ratenm
metrics.description: Percentage of cases with on-time deliveries. Only cases that have been completely delivered are considered.

metrics.description: Automation rate for a specific event

SUM(
	(SELECT COUNT(event_name)
	FILTER (
		WHERE ((${mts_automation_condition})
		AND event_name IN (${mts_automation_event_name})))))
/ SUM(
	(SELECT COUNT(event_name)
	FILTER (
		WHERE (event_name IN (${mts_automation_event_name})))))
*100

	WHERE event_name MATCHES(${itp_change_baseline_date})

/
COUNT(case_id)
* 100

metrics.description: Amount of cash discounts missed due to late payments

metrics.name: 3 Average delay of late deliveries

	(SELECT LAST(end_time)

	-(SELECT FIRST(end_time)
		WHERE event_name IN (${billing_creation_events}))
	)

COUNT(case_id) FILTER (
	WHERE (SELECT BOOL_OR(event_name ${change_events}) AND BOOL_OR(${manual_changes_condition})))
/ COUNT(case_id)
* 100

	-(SELECT FIRST(end_time)

/ COUNT (case_id) FILTER(
	WHERE (${itp_clearing_date} IS NULL)) * 100

metrics.name: Perfect order fulfillment rate
metrics.description: Percentage of cases that went through without any reversal of Goods Receipts
metrics.signalFragment:
(COUNT(case_id) FILTER (
	WHERE (event_name MATCHES(${goods_receipt_events}))
	)

	WHERE (${two_way_match_condition_ariba})
	)
/ COUNT(case_id)
* 100

metrics.name: Sourcing request conversion rate
metrics.description: Percentage of Sourcing Requests that were converted to a Sourcing Project
metrics.signalFragment:
COUNT(case_id) FILTER (
	WHERE (SELECT BOOL_OR(event_name IN (${sourcing_project_creation_events}))))
/ COUNT(case_id)
* 100

metrics.name: RFP savings vs historic spend
metrics.description: RFP (Request for Proposal) savings compared to historic spend. Indicates how much money your organization used to spend for this product/service (historic) versus how much they actually spent within RFP events.
metrics.signalFragment:
SUM(
	(SELECT SUM("Historic Total Cost") FILTER (
		WHERE (event_name IN (${rfp_creation_events})) 
        AND "Awarded Total Cost" > 0
        AND "Historic Total Cost" > 0))
	-(SELECT SUM("Awarded Total Cost") FILTER (
		WHERE (event_name IN (${rfp_creation_events})) 
        AND "Awarded Total Cost" > 0
        AND "Historic Total Cost" > 0))
)

metrics.name: Average supplier participation
metrics.description: Average supplier participation in sourcing events

metrics.name: Average invoice payment time
metrics.description: Average time to clear invoices
metrics.signalFragment:
AVG(
	(SELECT LAST(end_time)
		WHERE event_name IN (${invoice_clearing_events_ariba}))
	-(SELECT FIRST(end_time)
		WHERE event_name IN (${invoice_receipt_events_ariba}))
   )

metrics.name: Invoices waiting for Goods Receipt
metrics.description: Total number of cases with Invoices waiting for the Goods Receipt event
metrics.signalFragment:
COUNT(case_id) FILTER (
	WHERE NOT (event_name MATCHES(${goods_receipt_events_ariba}))
	AND (event_name MATCHES(${invoice_receipt_event_flow_ariba}))
	)

metrics.name: Auction savings vs historic spend
metrics.description: Auction savings compared to historic spend. Indicates how much money your organization used to spend for this product/service (historic) versus how much they actually spent within Auction events.
metrics.signalFragment:
SUM(
	(SELECT SUM("Historic Total Cost") FILTER (
		WHERE (event_name IN (${auction_creation_events})) 
        AND "Awarded Total Cost" > 0
        AND "Historic Total Cost" > 0))
	-(SELECT SUM("Awarded Total Cost") FILTER (
		WHERE (event_name IN (${auction_creation_events})) 
        AND "Awarded Total Cost" > 0
        AND "Historic Total Cost" > 0))
)

metrics.name: Late deliveries cases
metrics.description: Number of cases with late deliveries. Only cases that have been completely delivered are considered.

metrics.name: Average confirmation time for purchase requisitions
metrics.description: Average time needed to confirm a purchase requisition by creating a purchase order
metrics.signalFragment:
AVG(
	(SELECT LAST(end_time)
		WHERE event_name IN (${po_creation_events_ariba}))
	-(SELECT FIRST(end_time)
		WHERE event_name IN (${pr_creation_events_ariba}))
   )

metrics.name: Average time from purchase order to delivery
metrics.description: Average time from purchase order to goods receipt
metrics.signalFragment:
AVG(
	(SELECT LAST(end_time)
		WHERE event_name IN (${goods_receipt_events_ariba}))
	-(SELECT FIRST(end_time)

   )

metrics.name: Average sourcing request conversion duration
metrics.description: Average time it takes to convert a sourcing request to a Sourcing Project
metrics.signalFragment:
AVG(
	(SELECT LAST(end_time) FILTER (
		WHERE (event_name IN (${sourcing_project_creation_events}))))
	-(SELECT FIRST(end_time) FILTER (
		WHERE (event_name IN (${sourcing_request_creation_events}))))
   )

metrics.name: Average delay of late deliveries
metrics.description: The average delay time of late deliveries. Only cases that have been completely delivered are considered.

metrics.name: Average sourcing project cycle time
metrics.description: Average duration of a sourcing project from creation to close
metrics.signalFragment:
AVG(
	(SELECT LAST(end_time) FILTER (
		WHERE (event_name IN (${sourcing_project_closure_events}))))
	-(SELECT FIRST(end_time) FILTER (
		WHERE (event_name IN (${sourcing_project_creation_events}))))
   )

metrics.name: Late payments cycle time
metrics.description: Average payment cycle time of cases with late payments
metrics.signalFragment:
AVG(
	(SELECT LAST(end_time) FILTER 
		(WHERE event_name IN (${invoice_clearing_events_ariba})))
	-
	(SELECT FIRST(end_time) FILTER 
    	(WHERE event_name IN (${invoice_receipt_events_ariba})))
	) FILTER (
	WHERE (${late_payment_condition_ariba})
	AND ${invoice_clearing_date_ariba} IS NOT NULL
	)

COUNT(case_id) FILTER(

	)
/ COUNT(case_id)

metrics.name: Median Cycle Time between specific events
metrics.description: Median cycle time for a returns processing, ie the median cycle time between creating a return request and receiving the return. Cycle time is the time between two recorded events, in this case the first recorded instance of the 'Create Return Request' event, and last recorded instance of the 'Return Received' event across all cases.
metrics.signalFragment:
MEDIAN(
			   (SELECT LAST(end_time)
			    WHERE event_name = 'Receive Return')
			    -
               (SELECT FIRST(end_time)
                WHERE event_name = 'Create Return Request')
                )

metrics.name: Average cycle time
metrics.description: Average cycle time calculated from the first to the last event
metrics.signalFragment: AVG((SELECT LAST(end_time)) - (SELECT FIRST(end_time)))

blocks.text: This investigation was created to demonstrate some (process agnostic) mining use cases in Process Intelligence to support the AskData SIGNAL NLP Proof of Concept.
This template, along with the underlying data source is to be shared with our colleagues at AskData to train an NLP algorithm to translate simple process type questions into SIGNAL code.
The data source is an Order To Cash Process, however the example SIGNAL can be used for any process type.
The shape of the process data is outlined in the value widgets below
Each widget is configured with custom SIGNAL demonstrating query syntax for specific mining scenarios.

dataSource.query: SELECT count(case_id) FROM THIS_PROCESS

SELECT count(1) 
FROM FLATTEN(THIS_PROCESS)

SELECT count(1) / count(distinct case_id)
FROM FLATTEN(THIS_PROCESS)
SELECT count(DISTINCT event_name) FROM THIS_PROCESS

children.name: Cycle Time Example 1: Average cycle time across all cases

blocks.text: The Value Widget below is configured to show the average cycle time across all cases.
Cycle time is the time between two recorded events, in this case the first and last recorded event across all cases.

dataSource.query:
SELECT AVG((SELECT LAST(end_time) - FIRST(end_time))) AS "Average Cycle Time"
FROM THIS_PROCESS

children.name: Cycle Time Example 2: Median Cycle Time between Specific Events

blocks.text: The Value Widget below is configured to show the median cycle time for returns processing, ie the median cycle time between creating a return request and receiving the return.

Cycle time is the time between two recorded events, in this case the first recorded instance of the 'Create Return Request' event, and last recorded instance of the 'Return Received' event across all cases.

dataSource.query:
SELECT MEDIAN(
			   (SELECT LAST(end_time) 
			    WHERE event_name = 'Receive Return')
			    -
               (SELECT FIRST(end_time) 
                WHERE event_name = 'Create Return Request')
             ) AS "Median Return Cycle Time"
FROM THIS_PROCESS

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table Widget below is configured to show the top 5 process variants with their Average Cycle Times, ranked according to Case Count.
A process variant is a unique sequence of recorded events in a process (sometimes referred to as a trace).

children.name: Top 5 Variants and their Average Cycle Time, ranked by Case Count

dataSource.query:
SELECT event_name AS "Variant", 
  	   COUNT(DISTINCT case_id) as "Case Count",
       AVG((SELECT LAST(end_time) - FIRST(end_time))) AS "Average Cycle Time"
  FROM THIS_PROCESS
 GROUP BY 1
 ORDER BY 2 DESC
 LIMIT 5

children.name: Variant Example 2: Top X Variants by Percentile

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table Widget below is configured to show the maximum cycle time of 90% of all cases within each variant. For the purposes of the demo, we limit the results to the top 5 results.
A process variant is a unique sequence of recorded events in a process (sometimes referred to as a trace).

children.name: Top 5 Variants ranked by 90th Percentile Cycle Time

dataSource.query:
SELECT event_name AS "Variant", 
	  PERCENTILE_DISC(0.9) WITHIN GROUP(ORDER BY (SELECT LAST(end_time) - FIRST(end_time))) AS "90th Percentile Cycle Time per Variant"
  FROM THIS_PROCESS
 GROUP BY 1
 ORDER BY 2 DESC
 LIMIT 5

children.name: Rework Example 1: Cases with X repeated events

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table Widget below is configured to show cases with rework. Rework is identified by a number of repeated process steps exceeding a given threshold.
In this example, we show cases that have at least 1 event that is repeated at least 3 times.

children.name: Cases with Rework (Any event repeated more than 3 times)
children.description: Rework means the same event_name occurrent multiple times in the same case

dataSource.query:
SELECT case_id, "event_name", "end_time", "Risk Class" 
FROM THIS_PROCESS
WHERE (SELECT MAX(occ)
       FROM (SELECT OCCURRENCE(event_name) AS occ) AS sub) > 3
ORDER BY 1

children.name: Compliance Example 1: Compliance Rate for Standard Invoice Processing

blocks.text: The value widget below is configured to show the compliance rate for standard invoicing with payment received.
Compliance rate represents the count of cases exhibiting specific patterns / behaviours / sequences of events, divided by the total number of cases.
In this example we combine SIGNAL FILTER and MATCHES expressions count cases exhibiting a specific event pattern.

dataSource.query:
SELECT (
		COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE event_name MATCHES ('Create Invoice'~> 'Receive Payment'))
       /
       COUNT(1)
       ) * 100 AS "Standard Invoicing Compliance Rate"

FROM THIS_PROCESS

children.name: Pattern Matching Example 1: Unpaid Invoices (Standard Process Deviation)

blocks.text: The value widget below is configured to show the count of cases where invoice payment has not been received and customer risk class has not been assessed.

We calculate this by counting the cases exhibiting specific behaviours, specifically where the case level attribute 'Risk Class' = 'Not Evaluated' and the event 'Create Invoice' is not followed by the event 'Receive Payment' or 'Cancel Invoice'.
A behaviour is an expression evaluating case or event level attributes and can be used in a pattern matching expression.

children.name: Unpaid Invoices with Non Evaluated Risk Class

dataSource.query:
SELECT COUNT(1) AS "Case Count"
FROM THIS_PROCESS
WHERE "Risk Class" = 'Not evaluated'
AND
BEHAVIOUR
         (event_name = 'Create Invoice') AS create_invoice,
         ("Risk Class" = 'Not evaluated') AS no_risk_evaluation
MATCHES (no_risk_evaluation ~> create_invoice)
AND 
NOT event_name MATCHES ('Create Invoice' ~> 'Receive Payment')
AND
NOT event_name MATCHES ('Create Invoice' ~> 'Cancel Invoice')

children.name: Pattern Matching Example 2: Unpaid Invoices by Risk Class (Standard Process Deviation)

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table widget below is configured to show the count of cases where invoice payment has not been received according to customer risk class.

We calculate this by counting the cases exhibiting specific behaviours, specifically the event 'Create Invoice' is not followed by the event 'Receive Payment' or 'Cancel Invoice', and group the result by the case level attribute 'Risk Class'.
A behaviour is an expression evaluating case or event level attributes and can be used in a pattern matching expression.

children.name: Cases by Risk Class where Issued Invoice was neither followed by payment or cancelation

dataSource.query:
SELECT "Risk Class", 
	   COUNT(1) AS "Case Count"
FROM THIS_PROCESS
WHERE event_name 
MATCHES ('Create Invoice')
AND
NOT event_name 
MATCHES ('Create Invoice'
		~> 'Receive Payment')
AND
NOT event_name 
MATCHES ('Create Invoice'
		~> 'Cancel Invoice')
GROUP BY 1
ORDER BY 2 DESC

children.name: Timeseries Example 1: Active Cases within Period

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table widget below is configured to show the count of active cases per time period, meaning cases that were started at or before that period but not yet ended. In this example we consider the time period aggregated by months.

We calculate this by calculating a running count of first (case opened) and last (case closed) events per month. We then use the LAG function to subtract the previous period closed cases from the current period opened cases running count to get the total number of active cases started at or before the month but not yet ended.

dataSource.query:
SELECT "Month"
	   ,count_started AS "Cases Started During Month"
       ,count_finished AS "Cases Completed During Month"
       ,IF(count_started IS NOT NULL, count_started, 0) - IF(LAG(count_finished) OVER () IS NOT NULL, LAG(count_finished) OVER (), 0) AS "Active Cases"
  FROM (SELECT "Month"
             , SUM(count_started) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_started
             , SUM(count_finished) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_finished
          FROM (SELECT "Month"
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 1) AS count_started
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 0) AS count_finished
                  FROM (SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT FIRST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                  			   1 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS
                        UNION ALL
                        SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT LAST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                               0 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS) AS sub
                 GROUP BY 1
                 FILL TIMESERIES('month')
               ) AS sub2
       ) AS sub3

children.name: Time Series: Active cases by month

dataSource.query:
SELECT "Month"
       ,IF(count_started IS NOT NULL, count_started, 0) - IF(LAG(count_finished) OVER () IS NOT NULL, LAG(count_finished) OVER (), 0) AS "Active Cases"
  FROM (SELECT "Month"
             , SUM(count_started) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_started
             , SUM(count_finished) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_finished
          FROM (SELECT "Month"
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 1) AS count_started
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 0) AS count_finished
                  FROM (SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT FIRST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                  			   1 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS
                        UNION ALL
                        SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT LAST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                               0 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS) AS sub
                 GROUP BY 1
                 FILL TIMESERIES('month')
               ) AS sub2
       ) AS sub3

metrics.signalFragment:
SUM(
	(SELECT COUNT(event_name)
	FILTER (
		WHERE ((${mts_automation_condition})
		AND event_name IN (${mts_automation_event_name})))))
/ SUM(

metrics.description: Percentage of invoices that were cleared more than 5 days before their due dates

metrics.name: Average time invoice creation to invoice clearing
metrics.description: Average time from invoice creation to invoice clearing within a reference period
metrics.signalFragment:
AVG(
	(SELECT LAST(${itc_clearing_date}) 
		WHERE ((NOW() - LAST(end_time)) < DURATION ${itc_invoice_clearing_period}))
	-(SELECT LAST(${itc_posting_date})
		WHERE ((NOW() - LAST(end_time)) < DURATION ${itc_invoice_posting_period}))
	)

metrics.name: Average number of changes per case
metrics.description: Average number of change events per case
metrics.signalFragment:
AVG(
	(SELECT COUNT(event_name) FILTER (
		WHERE event_name ${change_events})))

metrics.name: Cancellation of Goods Receipts

COUNT(case_id) FILTER (
	WHERE (event_name MATCHES(${goods_receipt_reversal_events}))
	AND (event_name MATCHES(${goods_receipt_events}))
	)

metrics.name: Early payment rate
metrics.description: Percentage of invoices that were cleared more than 5 days before their due dates

metrics.name: Average time of goods receipt to invoice posting
metrics.description: Average time from receipt of goods to invoice posting
metrics.signalFragment:
AVG(
	(SELECT LAST(end_time) 
	WHERE event_name IN (${itp_invoice_posting_events})) 
	-
	(SELECT FIRST(end_time) 
	WHERE event_name IN (${itp_goods_receipt_events})))

metrics.name: Late purchase order creation
metrics.description: Total number of invoices where the purchase order item was created after the invoice creation

COUNT(case_id) FILTER(
	WHERE (event_name MATCHES(
(${itp_incompliant_activity_order}))))

metrics.name: Lost cash discount despite in-time payment
metrics.description: Amount of lost cash discounts in USD even though the invoice was paid in time for cash discount collection

metrics.name: Invoices without goods receipt
metrics.description: Total number of invoices without goods receipts
metrics.signalFragment:
COUNT(case_id)
	FILTER (WHERE NOT EVENT_NAME  MATCHES (${itp_goods_receipt_events})
		AND EVENT_NAME  MATCHES (${itp_invoice_posting_events}))

metrics.name: Lead time: invoice creation to accounts receivable clearing
metrics.description: Average lead time for items that were cleared within a reference period
metrics.signalFragment:
AVG(
	(SELECT LAST("InvoiceAccountingClearingDate") WHERE 
		((NOW() - LAST(end_time)) < DURATION ${invoice_clearing_period}))
	-(SELECT FIRST(${invoice_reference_date})WHERE 
		((NOW() - LAST(end_time)) < DURATION ${invoice_posting_period}))
	)

metrics.name: Two-way match rate

COUNT(case_id) FILTER (
	WHERE (${two_way_match_condition_ariba})

/ COUNT(case_id)
* 100

metrics.name: Sourcing request conversion rate

metrics.signalFragment:
COUNT(case_id) FILTER (
	WHERE (SELECT BOOL_OR(event_name IN (${sourcing_project_creation_events}))))
/ COUNT(case_id)
* 100

metrics.name: RFP savings vs historic spend
metrics.description: RFP (Request for Proposal) savings compared to historic spend. Indicates how much money your organization used to spend for this product/service (historic) versus how much they actually spent within RFP events.
metrics.signalFragment:
SUM(
	(SELECT SUM("Historic Total Cost") FILTER (
		WHERE (event_name IN (${rfp_creation_events})) 
        AND "Awarded Total Cost" > 0
        AND "Historic Total Cost" > 0))
	-(SELECT SUM("Awarded Total Cost") FILTER (
		WHERE (event_name IN (${rfp_creation_events})) 
        AND "Awarded Total Cost" > 0
        AND "Historic Total Cost" > 0))
)

metrics.name: Average supplier participation
metrics.description: Average supplier participation in sourcing events

metrics.name: Average invoice payment time
metrics.description: Average time to clear invoices

	(SELECT LAST(end_time)
		WHERE event_name IN (${invoice_clearing_events_ariba}))
	-(SELECT FIRST(end_time)

SUM(
	(SELECT SUM("Historic Total Cost") FILTER (
		WHERE (event_name IN (${auction_creation_events}))

	-(SELECT SUM("Awarded Total Cost") FILTER (

)

metrics.name: Average sourcing project cycle time

AVG(
	(SELECT LAST(end_time) FILTER (
		WHERE (event_name IN (${sourcing_project_closure_events}))))
	-(SELECT FIRST(end_time) FILTER (

   )

metrics.name: Late payments cycle time

AVG(
	(SELECT LAST(end_time) FILTER 
		(WHERE event_name IN (${invoice_clearing_events_ariba})))

	(SELECT FIRST(end_time) FILTER

	WHERE (${late_payment_condition_ariba})
	AND ${invoice_clearing_date_ariba} IS NOT NULL

metrics.name: Median Cycle Time between specific events
metrics.description: Median cycle time for a returns processing, ie the median cycle time between creating a return request and receiving the return. Cycle time is the time between two recorded events, in this case the first recorded instance of the 'Create Return Request' event, and last recorded instance of the 'Return Received' event across all cases.
metrics.signalFragment:
MEDIAN(
			   (SELECT LAST(end_time)
			    WHERE event_name = 'Receive Return')
			    -
               (SELECT FIRST(end_time)
                WHERE event_name = 'Create Return Request')
                )

metrics.name: Average cycle time
metrics.description: Average cycle time calculated from the first to the last event
metrics.signalFragment: AVG((SELECT LAST(end_time)) - (SELECT FIRST(end_time)))

metricVariables.description: List of events representing the creation of auctions, for example 'Create Auction'

metricVariables.description: Events defining the end point of the process for the cycle time calculation, for example 'Post Goods Issue'

metricVariables.name: start_events
metricVariables.description: Events defining the starting point of the process for the cycle time calculation, for example 'Create Sales Order Item'

metricVariables.name: conformance_condition
metricVariables.description: Sequence of events that describes the "to-be" process, for example, using the MATCHES function syntax ^ 'Create Sales Order Item' ~> 'Create Outbound Delivery Item' ~> 'Clear Invoice' $

metricVariables.name: jsm_sla_breached
metricVariables.description: Attribute defining the number of breached SLA

metricVariables.name: jsm_issue_change_condition

metrics.name: Average actual to target SLA ratio
metrics.description: Ratio between the average incident resolution duration to target SLA duration
metrics.signalFragment:
AVG(
	((SELECT LAST(end_time) WHERE event_name IN (${sla_closure_events}))
	-(SELECT FIRST(end_time) WHERE event_name IN (${sla_creation_events})))
) / (DURATION ${target_sla_time})
*100

metrics.name: Average cycle time
metrics.description: Average cycle time calculated from the first to the last event
metrics.signalFragment: AVG((SELECT LAST(end_time)) - (SELECT FIRST(end_time)))

metricVariables.name: sla_creation_events
metricVariables.description: Events defining the start events of a case, for example 'Create Incident'

metricVariables.name: target_sla_time
metricVariables.description: SLA time expectation, for example '15 days'

metricVariables.name: sla_closure_events
metricVariables.description: Events defining the closing events of a case, for example 'Close Incident'

blocks.text: This investigation was created to demonstrate some (process agnostic) mining use cases in Process Intelligence to support the AskData SIGNAL NLP Proof of Concept.
This template, along with the underlying data source is to be shared with our colleagues at AskData to train an NLP algorithm to translate simple process type questions into SIGNAL code.
The data source is an Order To Cash Process, however the example SIGNAL can be used for any process type.
The shape of the process data is outlined in the value widgets below
Each widget is configured with custom SIGNAL demonstrating query syntax for specific mining scenarios.

dataSource.query: SELECT count(case_id) FROM THIS_PROCESS

SELECT count(1) 
FROM FLATTEN(THIS_PROCESS)

SELECT count(1) / count(distinct case_id)
FROM FLATTEN(THIS_PROCESS)
SELECT count(DISTINCT event_name) FROM THIS_PROCESS

children.name: Cycle Time Example 1: Average cycle time across all cases

blocks.text: The Value Widget below is configured to show the average cycle time across all cases.
Cycle time is the time between two recorded events, in this case the first and last recorded event across all cases.

dataSource.query:
SELECT AVG((SELECT LAST(end_time) - FIRST(end_time))) AS "Average Cycle Time"
FROM THIS_PROCESS

children.name: Cycle Time Example 2: Median Cycle Time between Specific Events

blocks.text: The Value Widget below is configured to show the median cycle time for returns processing, ie the median cycle time between creating a return request and receiving the return.

Cycle time is the time between two recorded events, in this case the first recorded instance of the 'Create Return Request' event, and last recorded instance of the 'Return Received' event across all cases.

dataSource.query:
SELECT MEDIAN(
			   (SELECT LAST(end_time) 
			    WHERE event_name = 'Receive Return')
			    -
               (SELECT FIRST(end_time) 
                WHERE event_name = 'Create Return Request')
             ) AS "Median Return Cycle Time"
FROM THIS_PROCESS

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table Widget below is configured to show the top 5 process variants with their Average Cycle Times, ranked according to Case Count.
A process variant is a unique sequence of recorded events in a process (sometimes referred to as a trace).

children.name: Top 5 Variants and their Average Cycle Time, ranked by Case Count

dataSource.query:
SELECT event_name AS "Variant", 
  	   COUNT(DISTINCT case_id) as "Case Count",
       AVG((SELECT LAST(end_time) - FIRST(end_time))) AS "Average Cycle Time"
  FROM THIS_PROCESS
 GROUP BY 1
 ORDER BY 2 DESC
 LIMIT 5

children.name: Variant Example 2: Top X Variants by Percentile

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table Widget below is configured to show the maximum cycle time of 90% of all cases within each variant. For the purposes of the demo, we limit the results to the top 5 results.
A process variant is a unique sequence of recorded events in a process (sometimes referred to as a trace).

children.name: Top 5 Variants ranked by 90th Percentile Cycle Time

dataSource.query:
SELECT event_name AS "Variant", 
	  PERCENTILE_DISC(0.9) WITHIN GROUP(ORDER BY (SELECT LAST(end_time) - FIRST(end_time))) AS "90th Percentile Cycle Time per Variant"
  FROM THIS_PROCESS
 GROUP BY 1
 ORDER BY 2 DESC
 LIMIT 5

children.name: Rework Example 1: Cases with X repeated events

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table Widget below is configured to show cases with rework. Rework is identified by a number of repeated process steps exceeding a given threshold.
In this example, we show cases that have at least 1 event that is repeated at least 3 times.

children.name: Cases with Rework (Any event repeated more than 3 times)
children.description: Rework means the same event_name occurrent multiple times in the same case

dataSource.query:
SELECT case_id, "event_name", "end_time", "Risk Class" 
FROM THIS_PROCESS
WHERE (SELECT MAX(occ)
       FROM (SELECT OCCURRENCE(event_name) AS occ) AS sub) > 3
ORDER BY 1

children.name: Compliance Example 1: Compliance Rate for Standard Invoice Processing

blocks.text: The value widget below is configured to show the compliance rate for standard invoicing with payment received.
Compliance rate represents the count of cases exhibiting specific patterns / behaviours / sequences of events, divided by the total number of cases.
In this example we combine SIGNAL FILTER and MATCHES expressions count cases exhibiting a specific event pattern.

dataSource.query:
SELECT (
		COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE event_name MATCHES ('Create Invoice'~> 'Receive Payment'))
       /
       COUNT(1)
       ) * 100 AS "Standard Invoicing Compliance Rate"

FROM THIS_PROCESS

children.name: Pattern Matching Example 1: Unpaid Invoices (Standard Process Deviation)

blocks.text: The value widget below is configured to show the count of cases where invoice payment has not been received and customer risk class has not been assessed.

We calculate this by counting the cases exhibiting specific behaviours, specifically where the case level attribute 'Risk Class' = 'Not Evaluated' and the event 'Create Invoice' is not followed by the event 'Receive Payment' or 'Cancel Invoice'.
A behaviour is an expression evaluating case or event level attributes and can be used in a pattern matching expression.

children.name: Unpaid Invoices with Non Evaluated Risk Class

dataSource.query:
SELECT COUNT(1) AS "Case Count"
FROM THIS_PROCESS
WHERE "Risk Class" = 'Not evaluated'
AND
BEHAVIOUR
         (event_name = 'Create Invoice') AS create_invoice,
         ("Risk Class" = 'Not evaluated') AS no_risk_evaluation
MATCHES (no_risk_evaluation ~> create_invoice)
AND 
NOT event_name MATCHES ('Create Invoice' ~> 'Receive Payment')
AND
NOT event_name MATCHES ('Create Invoice' ~> 'Cancel Invoice')

children.name: Pattern Matching Example 2: Unpaid Invoices by Risk Class (Standard Process Deviation)

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table widget below is configured to show the count of cases where invoice payment has not been received according to customer risk class.

We calculate this by counting the cases exhibiting specific behaviours, specifically the event 'Create Invoice' is not followed by the event 'Receive Payment' or 'Cancel Invoice', and group the result by the case level attribute 'Risk Class'.
A behaviour is an expression evaluating case or event level attributes and can be used in a pattern matching expression.

children.name: Cases by Risk Class where Issued Invoice was neither followed by payment or cancelation

dataSource.query:
SELECT "Risk Class", 
	   COUNT(1) AS "Case Count"
FROM THIS_PROCESS
WHERE event_name 
MATCHES ('Create Invoice')
AND
NOT event_name 
MATCHES ('Create Invoice'
		~> 'Receive Payment')
AND
NOT event_name 
MATCHES ('Create Invoice'
		~> 'Cancel Invoice')
GROUP BY 1
ORDER BY 2 DESC

children.name: Timeseries Example 1: Active Cases within Period

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table widget below is configured to show the count of active cases per time period, meaning cases that were started at or before that period but not yet ended. In this example we consider the time period aggregated by months.

We calculate this by calculating a running count of first (case opened) and last (case closed) events per month. We then use the LAG function to subtract the previous period closed cases from the current period opened cases running count to get the total number of active cases started at or before the month but not yet ended.

dataSource.query:
SELECT "Month"
	   ,count_started AS "Cases Started During Month"
       ,count_finished AS "Cases Completed During Month"
       ,IF(count_started IS NOT NULL, count_started, 0) - IF(LAG(count_finished) OVER () IS NOT NULL, LAG(count_finished) OVER (), 0) AS "Active Cases"
  FROM (SELECT "Month"
             , SUM(count_started) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_started
             , SUM(count_finished) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_finished
          FROM (SELECT "Month"
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 1) AS count_started
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 0) AS count_finished
                  FROM (SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT FIRST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                  			   1 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS
                        UNION ALL
                        SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT LAST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                               0 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS) AS sub
                 GROUP BY 1
                 FILL TIMESERIES('month')
               ) AS sub2
       ) AS sub3

children.name: Time Series: Active cases by month

dataSource.query:
SELECT "Month"
       ,IF(count_started IS NOT NULL, count_started, 0) - IF(LAG(count_finished) OVER () IS NOT NULL, LAG(count_finished) OVER (), 0) AS "Active Cases"
  FROM (SELECT "Month"
             , SUM(count_started) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_started
             , SUM(count_finished) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_finished
          FROM (SELECT "Month"
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 1) AS count_started
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 0) AS count_finished
                  FROM (SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT FIRST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                  			   1 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS
                        UNION ALL
                        SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT LAST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                               0 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS) AS sub
                 GROUP BY 1
                 FILL TIMESERIES('month')
               ) AS sub2
       ) AS sub3

*100

metrics.name: Average cycle time
metrics.description: Average cycle time calculated from the first to the last event
metrics.signalFragment: AVG((SELECT LAST(end_time)) - (SELECT FIRST(end_time)))

blocks.text: This investigation was created to demonstrate some (process agnostic) mining use cases in Process Intelligence to support the AskData SIGNAL NLP Proof of Concept.
This template, along with the underlying data source is to be shared with our colleagues at AskData to train an NLP algorithm to translate simple process type questions into SIGNAL code.
The data source is an Order To Cash Process, however the example SIGNAL can be used for any process type.
The shape of the process data is outlined in the value widgets below
Each widget is configured with custom SIGNAL demonstrating query syntax for specific mining scenarios.

dataSource.query: SELECT count(case_id) FROM THIS_PROCESS

SELECT count(1) 
FROM FLATTEN(THIS_PROCESS)

SELECT count(1) / count(distinct case_id)
FROM FLATTEN(THIS_PROCESS)
SELECT count(DISTINCT event_name) FROM THIS_PROCESS

children.name: Cycle Time Example 1: Average cycle time across all cases

blocks.text: The Value Widget below is configured to show the average cycle time across all cases.
Cycle time is the time between two recorded events, in this case the first and last recorded event across all cases.

dataSource.query:
SELECT AVG((SELECT LAST(end_time) - FIRST(end_time))) AS "Average Cycle Time"
FROM THIS_PROCESS

children.name: Cycle Time Example 2: Median Cycle Time between Specific Events

blocks.text: The Value Widget below is configured to show the median cycle time for returns processing, ie the median cycle time between creating a return request and receiving the return.

Cycle time is the time between two recorded events, in this case the first recorded instance of the 'Create Return Request' event, and last recorded instance of the 'Return Received' event across all cases.

dataSource.query:
SELECT MEDIAN(
			   (SELECT LAST(end_time) 
			    WHERE event_name = 'Receive Return')
			    -
               (SELECT FIRST(end_time) 
                WHERE event_name = 'Create Return Request')
             ) AS "Median Return Cycle Time"
FROM THIS_PROCESS

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table Widget below is configured to show the top 5 process variants with their Average Cycle Times, ranked according to Case Count.
A process variant is a unique sequence of recorded events in a process (sometimes referred to as a trace).

children.name: Top 5 Variants and their Average Cycle Time, ranked by Case Count

dataSource.query:
SELECT event_name AS "Variant", 
  	   COUNT(DISTINCT case_id) as "Case Count",
       AVG((SELECT LAST(end_time) - FIRST(end_time))) AS "Average Cycle Time"
  FROM THIS_PROCESS
 GROUP BY 1
 ORDER BY 2 DESC
 LIMIT 5

children.name: Variant Example 2: Top X Variants by Percentile

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table Widget below is configured to show the maximum cycle time of 90% of all cases within each variant. For the purposes of the demo, we limit the results to the top 5 results.
A process variant is a unique sequence of recorded events in a process (sometimes referred to as a trace).

children.name: Top 5 Variants ranked by 90th Percentile Cycle Time

dataSource.query:
SELECT event_name AS "Variant", 
	  PERCENTILE_DISC(0.9) WITHIN GROUP(ORDER BY (SELECT LAST(end_time) - FIRST(end_time))) AS "90th Percentile Cycle Time per Variant"
  FROM THIS_PROCESS
 GROUP BY 1
 ORDER BY 2 DESC
 LIMIT 5

children.name: Rework Example 1: Cases with X repeated events

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table Widget below is configured to show cases with rework. Rework is identified by a number of repeated process steps exceeding a given threshold.
In this example, we show cases that have at least 1 event that is repeated at least 3 times.

children.name: Cases with Rework (Any event repeated more than 3 times)
children.description: Rework means the same event_name occurrent multiple times in the same case

dataSource.query:
SELECT case_id, "event_name", "end_time", "Risk Class" 
FROM THIS_PROCESS
WHERE (SELECT MAX(occ)
       FROM (SELECT OCCURRENCE(event_name) AS occ) AS sub) > 3
ORDER BY 1

children.name: Compliance Example 1: Compliance Rate for Standard Invoice Processing

blocks.text: The value widget below is configured to show the compliance rate for standard invoicing with payment received.
Compliance rate represents the count of cases exhibiting specific patterns / behaviours / sequences of events, divided by the total number of cases.
In this example we combine SIGNAL FILTER and MATCHES expressions count cases exhibiting a specific event pattern.

dataSource.query:
SELECT (
		COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE event_name MATCHES ('Create Invoice'~> 'Receive Payment'))
       /
       COUNT(1)
       ) * 100 AS "Standard Invoicing Compliance Rate"

FROM THIS_PROCESS

children.name: Pattern Matching Example 1: Unpaid Invoices (Standard Process Deviation)

blocks.text: The value widget below is configured to show the count of cases where invoice payment has not been received and customer risk class has not been assessed.

We calculate this by counting the cases exhibiting specific behaviours, specifically where the case level attribute 'Risk Class' = 'Not Evaluated' and the event 'Create Invoice' is not followed by the event 'Receive Payment' or 'Cancel Invoice'.
A behaviour is an expression evaluating case or event level attributes and can be used in a pattern matching expression.

children.name: Unpaid Invoices with Non Evaluated Risk Class

dataSource.query:
SELECT COUNT(1) AS "Case Count"
FROM THIS_PROCESS
WHERE "Risk Class" = 'Not evaluated'
AND
BEHAVIOUR
         (event_name = 'Create Invoice') AS create_invoice,
         ("Risk Class" = 'Not evaluated') AS no_risk_evaluation
MATCHES (no_risk_evaluation ~> create_invoice)
AND 
NOT event_name MATCHES ('Create Invoice' ~> 'Receive Payment')
AND
NOT event_name MATCHES ('Create Invoice' ~> 'Cancel Invoice')

children.name: Pattern Matching Example 2: Unpaid Invoices by Risk Class (Standard Process Deviation)

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table widget below is configured to show the count of cases where invoice payment has not been received according to customer risk class.

We calculate this by counting the cases exhibiting specific behaviours, specifically the event 'Create Invoice' is not followed by the event 'Receive Payment' or 'Cancel Invoice', and group the result by the case level attribute 'Risk Class'.
A behaviour is an expression evaluating case or event level attributes and can be used in a pattern matching expression.

children.name: Cases by Risk Class where Issued Invoice was neither followed by payment or cancelation

dataSource.query:
SELECT "Risk Class", 
	   COUNT(1) AS "Case Count"
FROM THIS_PROCESS
WHERE event_name 
MATCHES ('Create Invoice')
AND
NOT event_name 
MATCHES ('Create Invoice'
		~> 'Receive Payment')
AND
NOT event_name 
MATCHES ('Create Invoice'
		~> 'Cancel Invoice')
GROUP BY 1
ORDER BY 2 DESC

children.name: Timeseries Example 1: Active Cases within Period

blocks.text: The SIGNAL Table widget below is configured to show the count of active cases per time period, meaning cases that were started at or before that period but not yet ended. In this example we consider the time period aggregated by months.

We calculate this by calculating a running count of first (case opened) and last (case closed) events per month. We then use the LAG function to subtract the previous period closed cases from the current period opened cases running count to get the total number of active cases started at or before the month but not yet ended.

dataSource.query:
SELECT "Month"
	   ,count_started AS "Cases Started During Month"
       ,count_finished AS "Cases Completed During Month"
       ,IF(count_started IS NOT NULL, count_started, 0) - IF(LAG(count_finished) OVER () IS NOT NULL, LAG(count_finished) OVER (), 0) AS "Active Cases"
  FROM (SELECT "Month"
             , SUM(count_started) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_started
             , SUM(count_finished) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_finished
          FROM (SELECT "Month"
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 1) AS count_started
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 0) AS count_finished
                  FROM (SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT FIRST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                  			   1 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS
                        UNION ALL
                        SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT LAST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                               0 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS) AS sub
                 GROUP BY 1
                 FILL TIMESERIES('month')
               ) AS sub2
       ) AS sub3

children.name: Time Series: Active cases by month

dataSource.query:
SELECT "Month"
       ,IF(count_started IS NOT NULL, count_started, 0) - IF(LAG(count_finished) OVER () IS NOT NULL, LAG(count_finished) OVER (), 0) AS "Active Cases"
  FROM (SELECT "Month"
             , SUM(count_started) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_started
             , SUM(count_finished) OVER (ORDER BY "Month") AS count_finished
          FROM (SELECT "Month"
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 1) AS count_started
                     , COUNT(1) FILTER (WHERE started = 0) AS count_finished
                  FROM (SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT FIRST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                  			   1 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS
                        UNION ALL
                        SELECT date_trunc('month', (SELECT LAST(end_time))) AS "Month", 
                               0 AS started
                        FROM THIS_PROCESS) AS sub
                 GROUP BY 1
                 FILL TIMESERIES('month')
               ) AS sub2
       ) AS sub3
